InitialFeedbackHistory:
17/07/2024
Data:
Please note that the use of human cells is considered an ethical issue, please anwer yes to the ethics question and add the text with S number now described under data reuse 

Will a metadata standard be used to make it easier to find and reuse the data?
It seems like you have your project well documented. Everything you describe in this section is considered to be documentation (= Understandable & interpretable by any user (humans)) rather than metadata (= (Semi) structured information on data, preferably machine readable). 
Note that there are metadata standards available for some of the data you are generating. There are a couple for flow cytometry data (https://fairsharing.org/search?q=flow%20cytometry). You can search the fairsharing website (https://fairsharing.org/) to check whether there might be other standards for any of the other data types you have.
Images (especially the TIFF files) might have a standard set of metadata embedded in them derived from your measurement equipment. If this is the case for your images, you can mention this in this section as well.

Storage and preservation:
Where will the physical samples be stored and will they be preserved at the end of the project?

Data sharing:
You plan on publishing your experimental data sets and associated readme files involved in a publication on zenodo. Note that as a KU Leuven researcher, you can share your data through our institutional repository RDR as well (https://www.kuleuven.be/rdm/en/rdr). By uploading in RDR an uploaded dataset gets its own DOI, is registered in Lirias, and appears on your who-is-who publication list. This way your data is immediately integrated into the KU Leuven systems and you can get the full support for KU Leuven staff.
label: good with suggestions
